direction.raw_text: I'm sorry for his rudeness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have to understand what's happening to our children today, they're like wasps when you burn their nest. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right. Our children are saying 'that's enough!' Things have to change in this country. They accuse us of being cowards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emily, I have really come to assure you that I will do all I can to help you find out what really happened to Jonathan and your husband -- we cannot bring them back to life, but we can make sure that this sort of thing won't ever happen again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean well, sir, but it's better to forgive. If we keep the pain alive then hate and bitterness will remain with us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The air must be cleared.   So we can breathe again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The air can only be cleared if we forget about yesterday's thunder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Ben is right. It's not that I want to go on with this thing because it's a bad thing that Jonathan died, that Gordon died that's hard enough to bear, but I can forgive it. But they covered Gordon's name with dirt and we must clean it up, else he'll never have peace in his grave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You must understand for us, suicide is a coward's way out, how do they say, it's a 'cop out.'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gordon wasn't a coward and we'll prove that. We have a very good advocate for the inquest. His name is De Villiers. I have confidence in him and the truth will come out. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The truth must be known. They killed my husband who wouldn't hurt a fly and they killed Jonathan who was only a child...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Those people who did it are sinful people who don't know what they're doing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He! Mfundisi, what are you saying now? You mean...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We must help them. That's the only way. They need our help, not hate, but love.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I pity them and I ask the Lord to help me so I can learn to love them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If that's what you preach in your church you will soon be starving.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They covered his name with dirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aren't you afraid sis Emily?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. In the end one grows tired of being afraid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amen! Ben has been listening to the discussion with interest, this being the first time he has heard Africans talking seriously about their problems.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emily, Stanley and I will do all we can. As I said we have a good advocate. Everyone involved with Gordon's death will be questioned and all that's known regarding what happened in John Vorster Square will come out. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How can anything come out of that John Vorster Square? Who there will say: 'Yes, we killed the boy and Gordon?'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lawyers ask questions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And don't policemen lie?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Mr. Ben, sir for what you're doing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm pleased I came.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait, let me check the situation. He opens the door and walks out. EXT. EMILY'S HOUSE - AFTERNOON A small group of youngsters are there, hands thrust into their pockets, hanging around in a stony silence. Robert is standing by the door. Stanley calls one of them and talks to him -- the boys look around and say something. As Stanley goes back to the door, passing Robert, he ruffles his hair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take it easy. (then to Ben) It's okey, dokey, but hurry. Ben hurries out of the room.       The children stare at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do I... (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, on the floor man. Stanley opens the back door for Ben.     Who crouches on the floor. Some of the boys snicker and one bursts out laughing. As Stanley gets into the car he shouts at them:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. Kids, time to go home.   Be careful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure 'bra' Stanley. Take it easy. Stanley drives off at speed. EXT. OUTSKIRTS OF SOWETO - LATE AFTERNOON Stanley is driving, they have left Soweto.       Ben still on the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are we still in Soweto?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't you look for yourself? Ben rises and sees that they're at least a mile out.       He is not amused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the hell are you playing at?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Precautions, Lanie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't call me Lanie!   What does that mean anyway?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You will not understand, Lanie. They drive off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT. BEN'S BEDROOM - NIGHT Susan and Ben are in bed.    Susan is in Ben's arms, she is relaxed and loving. Ben talks quietly and calmly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think I am without awareness. I have always cared about people, call it a social conscience. But my visit to Gordon's house made me experience another dimension of human conditions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The poverty, ja...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I expected that. But listening to them talk made me realize that I did not know the blacks. Now I question my attitudes, my concerns as Ben, and complacence as a white person.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ben, I know your anxiety about the inquest. All will be cleared up, in a legal way, and you'll be back to your normal self. Now let's turn off the lights. Susan kisses Ben tenderly. INT. COURT ROOM - FIRST DAY OF INQUEST - DAY The inquest of Gordon Ngubene... conducted by MAGISTRATE KLOPPER. In the witness box is DR. JANSEN, the state pathologist, giving evidence. Advocate DE VILLIERS is cross examining.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dr. Jansen, you are a state pathologist of many years standing and I have no doubt a well-qualified pathologist. Could you now please tell us what caused the death of the deceased?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I found that death had been caused by the application of force to the neck, consistent with hanging. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: There's a vigorous reaction to this around the court, which gives us a chance to discover the crowd: In the white section of the public gallery are Ben and about eight other whites. The black section is filled to capacity with a few stand- ing. In the front row is sitting Stanley next to Margaret. At the entrance, a white policeman. In the press section are several reporters; amongst them Melanie Bruwer the Rand Daily Mail reporter. Colonel Viljoen and several policemen are sitting around the court.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are sure about the hanging? This pressure on the neck, could it also have been exerted in other ways?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It could, but it is not for me to speculate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course not, Doctor. The list of injuries found on the body was horrifyingly long; bruises, swellings, abrasions, broken rib, lacerations, etc. How long before death do you estimate he received these injuries?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I couldn't say exactly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roughly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some were fourteen to twenty days old, others three to four days and others even more recent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Even more recent. I see. I understand you had a Dr. Hassiem present at the autopsy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's correct. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There were two reports, ours and his. Did they tally?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, it was.   In most respects. ON Stanley listening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Isn't it normal practice to have one report? Why did Dr. Hassiem decide to draw up a separate report? If he really co-signed yours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's for him to answer!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would very much like to, Dr. Jansen, but he's been detained -- you know of course that he represented the Ngubene family. Thank you. There's a murmur around the court... Ben looks across at Viljoen who returns his gaze -- smiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dr. Herzog, did you examine the deceased?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, one day Captain Stolz called me in. The man had toothache.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's all?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As far as I could tell -- yes. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You didn't examine him thoroughly?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why should I? The man was perfectly healthy, just complaining of toothache. I extracted three decayed teeth, and gave him aspirin for the pain... that's all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did the captain or anyone else assist you during the examination?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I... I cannot remember.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dr. Herzog, tell us. Have you been intimidated by the Security Police or did you deliberately cooperate with them in playing their disgusting little game of hide-and-seek?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I protest, Your Worship.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Advocate De Villiers, will you refrain from insinuations?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Doctor Herzog... I'm sure Gordon Ngubene was extremely grateful! Herzog's face is impassive. ON crowd reacting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Advocate Louw? During the hubbub De Villiers and the state advocate trade places. The courtroom is quiet. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Your Worship. I'd like to call Captain Stolz. There's a buzz from the spectators as Captain Stolz walks up to the witness stand. He's given a Bible. ON Ben -- watches him. CLOSEUP - STOLZ In witness box, swearing in Afrikaans.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a police officer stationed at John Vorster Square?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right, Your Worship.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You arrested Gordon Ngubene. Could you describe what happened?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Acting on information we had received, I went to the house of the deceased, accompanied by Lieutenant Venter, Lieutenant Botha, and three native members of the security force. This was about 10 P.M. I informed Ngubene that he was under arrest under Article 6 of the Terrorism Act. He then became violent and resisted arrest. A certain force had to be applied to restrain him. ON Stanley listening. ON Ben listening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We found several incriminating documents. These pointed to his involvement with the A.N.C. and activities endangering the security of the state.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ON Ben looking at Stolz, and shaking his head, bewildered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Was the deceased ever assaulted to your knowledge?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Never. He was always treated with courtesy and correctness. But, one time we had cause to use force against him. It was the day before his death. The deceased suddenly showed signs of aggression. He tried to jump through the open window of my office. He was acting like a mad man. It took six of my men to restrain him, and he had to be manacled hand and foot, for his own safety. But once he calmed down, he was ready to make a statement about his activities. The next morning we found him dead in his cell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is the statement in evidence?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Your Worship. It can't be disclosed in court without damaging our investigation, but I would like to offer into evidence a suicide note written by the deceased. Louw, taking it from his file on the table. Stanley and Margaret listening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Dear Captain. I prefer to die rather than betray any more of my friends. Amandla! Gordon Ngubene.' He hands it to the court clerk.   There's uproar at this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Your Worship.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Advocate De Villiers? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: Ben is disgusted. He looks about the court, as if seeking allies. His eyes meet Melanie's -- just for a second there's recognition -- then he returns to De Villiers. Advocate De Villiers cross-examining Captain Stolz.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Your Worship. Captain Stolz, you said you treated the deceased always with courtesy and correctness, then how do you account for the injuries found on the body?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sometimes detainees deliberately injure themselves for propaganda purposes. The gallery screams its objections. Stanley leans forward and grins across the partition at Ben. The Magistrate warns the crowd. Finally the gallery quiets down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You say he tried to jump out of the open window... Are there no bars to prevent such an act?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They had been removed for repair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And why did he wish to jump out? Because you were torturing him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He wasn't tortured.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Perhaps it was the toothache then. No reaction from Stolz.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You said you seized incriminating documents at the deceased's home; can you produce them to see how subversive he was?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Those documents cannot be introduced as evidence, Your Worship, in view of the fact that state security is involved. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: The Magistrate makes a note.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I put it to you, Captain -- that the only subversive activities the deceased had been involved in were his efforts to establish what happened to his son, Jonathan, allegedly shot during a riot, although several witnesses are prepared to testify that he died in detention one month later.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I protest...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This would support my case that an innocent man has died in your hands under highly questionable circumstances.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If it please Your Worship... this unwarranted slur on the integrity of the special branch is unacceptable... and based, I may say, on allegations which are in any case irrelevant to the present inquest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I agree.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If the police are really interested in retaining an unsullied reputation, they should not object to the real facts being presented. Thank you, Captain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The real facts are being presented
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (like an actor, with big expansive gesture)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as she sits on the broken chair)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Ben as he goes to the door)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : DR. HERZOG the police physician, giving evidence.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as the following affadivits prove. They are all by detainees
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: who testify that they had all seen the deceased intermittently from the time of his detention -- to the time of his death -- and on all occasions he was in good health. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: As the documents are passed to the Magistrate, they are scorned by De Villiers. Imperviously he requests:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I trust the signatories of these ... documents... are available to corroborate their evidence in person. STRAIGHT ON ARCHIBALD CHIGORIMBO Detainee in the witness box.    He swears in Zulu. De Villiers holds his signed affidavit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Archibald, when did you first meet Gordon Ngubene?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I never saw Gordon Ngubene. A sudden stillness in the court. ON Ben. ON Stanley. ON Melanie. ON Louw.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you saying that you didn't sign this statement?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... I never met Mr. Ngubene... they forced me to sign. Captain Stolz, he hit me many times with a rubber hose... he said he would kill me 'less I signed... this... this is what he did to me. He pulls up his shirt -- his back is covered in bruises. The crowd cannot restrain itself any longer.     Ben is aghast by what he sees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Mr. Archibald. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Advocate Louw?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No thank you, Your Worship. As Archibald leaves the witness stand, held by a special branch officer, he raises his fist in salute and shouts to the crowd: "AMANDLA." The crowd responds: "Ngawethu." Ben looks at Archibald. He is very impressed by this strength in the prisoner's eyes. An officer   of the court shouts at the crowd: "silte in die koort"   (silence in court) -- bailiffs collar a few of the loudest   protesters and pull them with brutality out of the   courtroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: May we put up the second signatory? Louw confers hurriedly with the prosecution officers, then turns back to the court.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your Worship -- the other three signatories cannot appear for reasons of state security. He sits down, bland, examining his papers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your Worship, I'd like to recall Captain Stolz. As Captain Stolz returns to the stand he crosses Archibald being handcuffed by the S.B. officer. Ben watches him passing by the detainee, straight, im- passive without a look to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Captain, you're still under oath
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (looking at black crowd, then to De Villiers)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: you took Archibald's statement. Was it voluntary? I'm sure you'll say it was, then how did he come by the injuries on his back?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He fell down the stairs a few days ago. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fell down the stairs. You should do something about those stairs, Captain, so many people fall on them. Thank you. The crowd laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your Worship, may I be excused? I have to escort detainee Archibal back to John Vorster Square.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You may, Captain, and thank you. (to the crowd) I think this's a good moment to adjourn -- we'll reconvene at two thirty. EXT. COURTROOM - DAY Emily, Margaret, Stanley and a man, are sitting outside the court eating fish and chips. There are various Africans sitting around for their lunch break.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: De Villiers is making mincemeat of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's very good. His cross- examination has got them rattled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's obvious to anybody! The evidence is clear! (pause) Did you see Archibal's back? He didn't have to tell the truth. Dan Lewinson's dry laugh catches in his throat. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what Stolz is saying to him right now in his torture room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Captain Stolz lied. My husband never fight the police when he was arrested. They were rough with him, pushing him and threatening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When your husband's clothes were given to you, in what condition were they?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There was blood on them and in the back pocket I found three broken teeth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now Mrs. Ngubene, you have seen the note that's said to have been written by your husband. Do you recognize the writing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's not how my husband writes. (strongly) He never wrote that letter, they lie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Mrs. Ngubene.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Advocte Louw? He shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They killed my husband and son. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: ON Ben, satisfied.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will you take the woman out?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd like to call my last witness. Grace Nkosi. Grace's name is called. She is an attractive 20-years- old girl. As she passes by Ben, he watches her with concern; her face looks familiar. Of course he remembers having seen her at John Vorster Square the first time he went there to meet the colonel. GRACE NKOSI is the African girl the two security officers were lifted to the ten flour. He recognizes her. Grace Nkosi in the witness stand. She swears in Xhosa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Were you ever detained?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes sir, at John Vorster Square.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For how long?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Six months.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can you tell us what happened to you during that time?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was interrogated by many special policemen, but mainly Captain Stolz and the one they call Venter. As they were searching somebody I know, they wanted me to tell them where that person was hidden. As I refuse to cooperate they beat me with a sjambok. After some time I fell and they kicked me in the face and stomach. ON Ben obviously shocked. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I spot blood and they try to make me lick it. Then Captain Stolz threw a wet towel and started twisting it around my neck... (she illustrates) ... until I lost consciousness. They did this several time and the last one Captain Stolz said 'come on meid, speak up, or do you want to die like Gordon Ngubene?' A few days later I was released. ON Melanie taking notes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Miss Grace. That's all, Your Worship.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You made that up. Say you made it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's the truth. I have nothing more to say. Louw sits down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We shall adjourn until tomorrow morning. I'll hear the arguments and give the verdict. The crowd stands and starts to leave the courtroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wish to thank both advocates for conducting this case without rancour and in the best traditions of the South African legal profession. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: ON Ben's face.    ON Dan Lewinson's face.   ON Viljoen and Stolz's faces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have listened to all the evidence and the arguments. To begin with I have to say that there was no conclusive evidence offered to prove beyond doubt that members of the Security Police had been guilty of assault or any irregular conduct on the deceased. There were indications that Ngubene was aggressive and on more than one occasion had to be restrained with force. There was sufficient evidence to conclude that death had been caused by a trauma following pressure applied to the neck, consistent with hanging. Consequently, I find that Gordon Ngubene committed suicide by hanging himself and that on available evidence his death cannot be attributed to any act or omission or amounting to a criminal offense on the part of any person.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry, man. There's another day! Ben leans towards Emily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, Emily. Several press photographers are taking pictures osten- sibly of Emily the widow. Stanley gently guides Emily out of the building. Ben, who is following, is besieged by the insistent reporters, shouting:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Mister Du Toit, how do you know Mrs. Ngubene?' 'Mister Du Toit, can you answer, is it true, he was a terrorist?' Ben tries to get through.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mister Du Toit, what do you think of the verdict? Do you believe the police? Melanie appears, grabs Ben and pushes him away through them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hang on, Melanie, I'm coming with you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fuck off. The press is still pursuing them. As Ben and Melanie reach Melanie's car:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My car is over there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Never mind your car. Let's get away from these vultures. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: They get into the car and as they drive away, Melanie introduces herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By the way, I'm Melanie Bruwer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Obviously of the Rand Daily Mail. I read your article about Jonathan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ten out of ten, Mr. Du Toit.      I know about you too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You do? Melanie smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have a mutual friend.    One Stanley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I remember. The mortuary in Soweto... (pause) ... The ambiguous Stanley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stanley? No. Just careful. A big black rough uncut diamond. Don't be fooled by his happy-go- lucky attitude. There's much more to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He couldn't have given you a glowing report of me. (suddenly aggressive) I'm sorry, but where are we going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought a cooling drink at my house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Bruwer, I'm not... (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I promise you. I'm not after an interview or anything like that. She smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I really must go home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, Mr. Du Toit, and you'll meet my darling father. She smiles again.    A disarming smile. EXT. MELANIE'S HOME - DAY Melanie drives into the yard. The house is an old Colonial style house amidst flowers, bushes and trees, a controlled wild garden. A figure is bent over a beehive. A large brimmed old hat with a net hides his head and features. Melanie stops the car in the driveway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There he is by the eucalyptus tree, on the left. That's old Bruwer. They get out of the car and walk towards him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long have you lived here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, about twenty-one years.   I love this house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that you, Melanie?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course, Dad. I want you to meet a friend.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does anyone have a friend nowadays? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: He straightens up and throws the net over his head and studies Ben. MR. BRUWER is seventy years old; an interesting face with a goatee beard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Du toit, Dad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you like bees?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have nothing against them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Be careful, I can see philosophy coming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You shut up. (to Ben) Let me tell you about bees, and for that matter ants: a bee has a completely altruistic sense of purpose -- based on the common good. A course from which he cannot be deflected. Greed, ambition, they mean nothing to him. He lives solely to serve his fellow bee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about individuality, Dad?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's the rub, my girl. There's the rub. One of these days I'll ask the bees. I'm sure they have the answer. Now, you two run along! He replaces his net and continues with the hive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A drink, Dad?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've been peeing too much this morning. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's my Daddy. Melanie and Ben enter the house. INT. MELANIE'S LIVING ROOM - DAY The Bruwer living room is a profusion of piles of papers, of books on shelves, on tables, on the floor, paintings -- records, African sculptures. On the floor tangled lengths of flex leading from a record player to two voluminous speakers. A settee, a chess set. The furniture is old and well- used, dominated by a large leather club chair -- two big cats sleeping on it. It's civilized pandemonium.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now you see in what environment I was spawned. Ben looks at the shelves and smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please sit down, on that chair. (pointing to club chair) That's Dad's. Drink?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please.   A...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A brandy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No thanks, a beer will be fine. Melanie goes into the kitchen leaving Ben. He cannot forget what he heard and what he saw in the court! She returns barefooted, with two beer mugs, and hands one to Ben. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The mugs are the few things that Dad brought from Germany. He studied philosophy in Tubingen and Berlin before the last war.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought they were German? Melanie sits, her legs propped up on the settee, hugging her knees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Du Toit, tell...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, call me Ben.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, Ben, tell me, why are you so depressed? You really expect a different verdict?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why do you ask? Can you understand it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course I understand it. What could they have. I'm not cynical. I'm only trying to be realistic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me, Miss Bruwer...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ben and Melanie, that's fair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me, do you believe in the notion of justice?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll never stop believing. But in this country I've learned it's pointless to look for it in certain situations.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What use is a system if justice does not apply to all situations? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Exactly. And you cannot fight for justice unless you know injustice very well. You've got to know your enemy first.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's a tall order: 'know injustice... know the enemy.' it seems I have a long haul ahead of me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not at all, Ben. You have already taken the first steps. (pause) Welcome to South Africa! She smiles. INT. BEN'S BEDROOM - NIGHT Susan is sitting at the dressing table. She is applying cleansing cream to her face. She is relaxed. Ben is getting ready for bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you enjoy the 'bobotie?' When I heard the verdict on the news I knew you'd be upset. (softer) I wanted to make you something special.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, darling. A pause.     Susan starts to remove the cream.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm glad it's all over. You take things to heart too much. Ben comes and stands behind Susan -- looking at her through the mirror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They killed Gordon -- first they kill Jonathan, and then him. How can they get away with it? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now come on, Ben. Gordon's death upset me, too. But the Magistrate had all the facts. He must know what he's doing, he's had years of experience. The case has run its course, and nobody can do anything more about it! It's all over and done with.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not so sure about that, Susan! Susan swivels around and faces Ben.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm damned well sure! It's over, Ben! You better get that into your head. Ben just stares at her with seething anger.       She stands up and starts being hysterical.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A teacher, always a bloody teacher. You never moved yourself for us. But for the blacks, oh yes. Whose side are you on, Ben? And I'm sick and tired of those natives coming here. Why don't you bloody well go and live in Soweto? Ben strides out of the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now where are you going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Soweto! Then shuts the door behind him. Susan stands stupefied.    There's the sound of the SPARE ROOM DOOR. INT. SPARE ROOM - NIGHT Ben is standing in the middle of the room, in the dark. On the wall behind him is a young Suzette's picture. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: After a few seconds, Ben moves slowly to the bed and sits on it still in deep thought. SLOW MOVE TO a: CLOSEUP ON BEN And:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ben goes into a newspaper shop. There are two children buying sweets and a woman leaving. The PROPRIETOR is an Afrikaner in his middle age.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: More meneer Van de Merwe. (Morning Mister Van de Merwe.)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: More meneer du Toit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Our boys gave the Eastern province a thrashing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Ben realizes that the man is not his usual conversational self.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is anything wrong?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Ben goes to pick up an Afrikaans newspaper and the Rand Daily Mail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And a packet of tobacco and pipe cleaners. The man gets them and takes a note from Ben and gives him his change. By then a man is waiting. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See you tomorrow. As he walks out the other man turns around to watch him. EXT. STREET - MORNING Ben walks    out of the shop. The newspaper under his arm. A group of    three middle-aged women turn to look at him. Ben didn't    see them. A little further on, he meets Mrs. Coetzee.     He tries to greet her but she walks straight by. Further on, he notices two men obviously talking about him. Then a couple of boys on bikes snigger as they pass him. He begins to wonder what's it all about, and spontaneously checks his clothes. EXT. BEN'S HOUSE - VERANDA - MORNING Susan and Suzette sit there. Suzette's holding a news- paper -- the Ossewa -- Susan's thoughtful, her face is red and discomposed -- obviously she had cried. The PHONE RINGS but they deliberately ignore it. Ben appears with the newspapers under his arm, sees Suzette's sports car and hurries to join them. Suzette doesn't even give him a chance to kiss her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, Papa, this is going too far! How could you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How's that, Suzette? Ben takes the newspaper and looks at the cover. A picture of himself and Emily outside the courtroom. The two faces are close together with the notes:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. CAFE NEAR COURT - DAY Ben and Dan Lewinson having a light lunch in a nearby cafe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. COURTROOM - AFTERNOON Advocate De Villiers and a dignified Emily in the witness stand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (facing the Magistrate and in firm voice)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rising and looking at Grace for some seconds)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. COURTROOM - MORNING (SECOND DAY) A silent black crowd; Emily, Margaret, Stanley anxiously awaiting the verdict. Today the public gallery is more crowded than before.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : Viljoen and Stolz smiling, shaking hands with Advocate Louw in congratulations.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. FOYER OF COURTROOM - DAY The predominantly black crowd obviously dissatisfied with the verdict, discussing it as it moves slowly towards the main entrance. In the crowd Stanley, Margaret and Emily controlled, dignified but obviously pained.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : BEN totally depressed, walking up to Emily. (CONTINUED)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Ben over noise of the discussion)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . FADE IN: INT. NEWSPAPER AND CONFECTIONARY SHOP - MORNING It's a Saturday morning. A shopping center in a white suburb.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (jumping up and showing the cover of Ossewa)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: wife of native who died in detention, comforted by a friend of family, Mr. BEN DU TOIT." And in parenthesis "see page two." He throws the Ossewa on a chair and checks into the Rand Daily Mail. Inside there is a long article with Emily's picture, titled "the Face of Grief." Ben folds up the newspapers, and shakes his head. He suddenly realizes why the people reacted like that outside. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You didn't stop to think of the family. Poor mother, how can she face anyone? And tomorrow is Sunday!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now listen... Johan steps into the veranda.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's everybody yelling about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You listen, Papa, just tell me, why? Recognizing his father in the photo, Johan has picked up the newspaper from the chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you really think I specially arranged for the photographers to take that picture? And what's more it's distorted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's distorted about it? Your face is practically touching that meid's face, like you were about to kiss her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suzette, pull yourself together!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Today the whole country has seen that photograph. We, your children, are going to suffer. At this very moment Chris is negotiating with the Provincial Council. Would you like to see them cancel it? You have no feeling, Papa!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suzette! She leaves in rage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's Papa done, anyway? If something happened to him, wouldn't you be upset? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not enough, Johan, to throw myself into the garden boy's arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That goes without saying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There must be easier ways of getting your name in the paper. Before she can stop herself, Susan slaps him across the face, although not hard. Johan leaves without a word. She clutches her hand, shocked at having it against him. The PHONE starts to RING.    Susan runs out sobbing. Ben looks at her then walks into the living room to pick up the phone. INT. BEN'S LIVING ROOM - MORNING BEN (into phone) Who?... I don't know you and have nothing to say to you... No thank you for your advice! He puts the phone down.    The PHONE RINGS again.   Ben picks it up and waits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's you, Viviers... I appreciate it... of course... Not yet... Any thank you. Tot siens. He replaces the receiver and is about to light his pipe when the PHONE RINGS again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Morning, Mr. Cloete...   I'd like to say... (impatiently) ... Mr. Cloete, may I ask what on earth has the picture to do with politics?... I'm sorry Mr. Cloete, I have to go. He replaces the telephone and walks out of the house. The PHONE KEEPS RINGING.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EXT. BESTER'S FARM - COUNTRY - DAY The farm is a typical transvaal farm covering thousands of acres.  In the distance there's a range of mountains. Several cattle are grazing, herded by a poorly-clad African and his son, aged 8 years. Bester and Ben are leaning on the wooden fence of the cattle kraal with calves penned in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everything was examined in depth in court.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you read the papers, Dominee? Were you happy with what came to light? And is it the Magistrate's work to pretend that the facts which came to light didn't exist?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Was it really facts, Ben? Just then the African "HERDBOY" walks up to them taking off his lattered greasy hat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ja?   What is it Tom?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does the Baas want me to bring the bull now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Later, Tom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dankie, Baas. Tom hurries away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I bought a bull last week.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know, Gordon. What they said about him, that he was plotting against the government -- is a downright lie. He was only doing what I would have done as a father; searching for his son.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No one but God can see what's in our hearts. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Isn't it presumptuous to pretend we can speak for someone else?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you no faith in your fellow men, Dominee? Don't you love your neighbor?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait a minute, instead of criticizing blindly, don't you think we have reason to be proud of the judiciary we have?  suppose this had been Russia; what do you think would have happened then?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the use of reaching a court when a handful of people have all the power to decide what is going to be said in that court and by whom? The one man they allowed to speak for himself, that young Archibald Chigorimbo, didn't he immediately deny everything they forced him to say in his statement? And the girl who spoke of her own torture?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That did not refer to our situation in this South Africa. Do you know what I believe in, Dominee, that once in one's life, just once, one should have enough faith in something to risk everything for it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One can gain the world and still lose one's soul. Tea must be ready. Bester and Ben walk towards the house still in conversation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT. DAN PIENAAR SCHOOL - MORNING The staff is having coffee during morning break in the staff room. The room has several easy chairs, a table with the morning newspapers on it. The walls have pictures of South African scenes. There are several conversations in Afrikaans.   This is the first morning since the photograph. Ben walks into the staff room. The conversations stop. Everyone looks at him with hostility. The teachers all place their cups on the table and quietly file out of the room. Ben pours himself a cup of coffee; as he takes his first sip, Cloete looks in, sees him. He walks in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope you don't mind us talking here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't mind, Mr. Cloete.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll come to the point. You can't imagine how shocked I was by that scandalous photograph in the Ossewa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The woman lost her husband, she was shattered with grief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kaffir woman, Du Toit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (angrily) I can't see that it makes any difference.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you gone color blind then? And what about the apartheid laws? Our first responsibility as teachers is the reputation of the school, the pupils entrusted to us. We have to be an example to them in and out of this school yard. Ben looks at him calmly. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought I had warned you about involving yourself with Kaffirs. Obviously you didn't heed my advice.  That's all I have to say for now. Cloete walks out of the room. Viviers hurries into the room, he is late for his coffee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Morning, Oom Ben.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Viviers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Private coffee with Cloete? Ben picks up the copy of the Ossewa with the photograph and shows it to Viviers. EXT. MELANIE'S HOME - DAY Ben stops the car in the Bruwer driveway. From the driving seat he searches the garden for Bruwer. He walks up to the front door and knocks, but there's no reply. He goes 'round to the back and finds the old man on his knees weeding his vegetable garden.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good afternoon, Professor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Melanie isn't home. You are...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ben Du Toit. You have a nice vegetable garden.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean the area or the produce?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Both.   What plants are these? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the world coming to? It's herbs, can't you see? Thyme there, oregano over there, feunel next to the tomatoes, sage here and rosemary somewhere. Poor plants, they re not in their ideal soil or climate. Next time, I'll bring some soil from the mountain of Zeus. Perhaps the old man's holiness will do the trick. He throws down the small weeding-fork.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come, you are just the person to sample my greengage wine. I don't suppose you've ever tasted it? I'm sure I'm the only person in the country making greengage wine. He leads Ben to the two old chairs by the back wall. He enters the kitchen and returns with a bottle of greengage wine and two glasses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The first bottle this year, and you don't have to tell me if you like it or not. Tell me, did you ever study philosophy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not really.   I've read a few books.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not bad, in fact quite good. Now where was I... Oh, I was going to say after decades of philosophy, I find myself being forced back to the earth. Do you know, Ben, we're all living in the spell of abstractions. Hitler, apartheid, the great American dream, the lot?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about Jesus?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Misunderstood. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't have to finish it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's quite nice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Melanie has told me a little about you. It's not an easy road you have chosen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I feel I have no choice. Bruwer farts loudly, Ben is taken aback, but the Professor continues.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course you have a choice. Damn it. One always has a choice. Only thank God you made the choice you did. But all I want to say is, keep your eyes open, young man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's encouraging.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are both Boers, Ben. We know how hard our people worked to get a toehold on this land; it was a good life. Now look at the mess. It's all systems and no God! Sooner or later people start believing in their way of life as an absolute: unmutable, fundamental, a precondition. Saw it, with my own eyes in Germany, a nation running after an idea. Sieg heil, sieg heil. I left there thirty years ago because I couldn't take it any longer. And now I see it happening in my own country, step by step. Terrifyingly predictable. This sickness of the great abstraction. He farts and sips his greengage wine. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: Ben is so fascinated by the old man's conversation he didn't react. He is learning form his old Afrikaner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What you say is very interesting and important.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take for example the way the government is handling the electorate; like a bloody donkey. Carrot in front and kick at the backside. The carrot is apartheid, Dogma. The kick is quite simply, fear. Black peril, red peril, whatever name you want to give it. (pause) Fear can be a wonderful ally, Ben. I talk too much, I always do with younger people, they don't fall asleep to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We Afrikaners have to stop to turn a blind eye and look around us and at ourselves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are right. We still have time. History should teach us about those who regarded themselves as the chosen people.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Professor Bruwer, may I say I have needed to hear somebody say some of the things you said. I still have hope for our country.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you lose that you have lost everything. I'll get back to the earth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll tell that hot-head daughter of mine that you came to see her. Ben takes his leave. INT. LEWINSON'S OFFICE - DAY Ben and Dan Lewinson are sitting opposite, cups of coffee in front of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is absolutely no doubt that they were killed in custody. Those responsible must be punished, whoever they are, or whatever their rank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The problem is laying our hands on them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me, Dan, we lost at the inquest, what next?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The family can file a civil claim.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What does that entail?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To put it briefly, it means we have to have witnesses, affidavits and any information relating to the arrest and death of Gordon. We also need similar information on Jonathan. You see Ben, for example, Stolz figures in both cases. That's one link at least.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know what I have to do. EXT. ROADSIDE CAFE - AFTERNOON It's lunch time and the working population of Jo'burg has paused for lunch. Ben and Melanie are sitting at a table outside. The cafe is on the outskirts of a very affluent part of Johannesburg. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't think you would want to have anything to do with me after that crap in the Ossewa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?   You didn't write it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm a journalist, perhaps tarred with the same brush.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So what happened? I can imagine. The family, the dominee, colleagues, neighbors...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A distorted photograph and a few poisoned words and meneer Du Toit is a leper. That's why I called on you the other day, I needed to talk to somebody rational.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks for the compliment. But remember, you're an Afrikaner, you're one of them. In their eyes they regard you as the worst kind of traitor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are an Afrikaner too, and your articles, in a liberal English paper?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My mother was a foreigner, I'm not pure, wragte Afrikaner. They don't expect the same loyalty from me that they demand from you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What kind of loyalty? Blind loyalty. Until the deaths of Jonathan and Gordon, I gave all the loyalty I could give, laager loyalty. You know, Melanie, we Afrikaners have always lived in our laager, we have not seen what's beyond the mountains. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Has it ever occurred to you that the Volk may be scared to leave the laager? That's the downfall of this country. So, where do you go from here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We carry on.   There has to be justice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Justice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We lost at the inquest, so we pursue them in a civil action.    I consulted the attorney Dan Lewinson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We know each other well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: #'S 107 - 110 MISSING STOLZ Mr. Du Toit, if you knew what we're working with every day of our lives, and what we're up against, you would understand why we have to be so thorough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: However you go about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can understand you're upset about having your house searched ... but...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wasn't thinking about myself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you talking about then, Mr. Du Toit?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My thoughts, Captain, I'm sure, are an open book to you. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: Stolz picks up a book of Picasso's Peace Paintings, starts leafing through it carefully, scrutinizing each page. He puts the Picasso book carefully back in the place he took it from.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An interesting book -- Picasso -- Not one I'm familiar with.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not on your list of banned books, Captain? Stolz doesn't react...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Susan is standing pale, rigid, shocked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Du Toit. If you're keeping anything from us, we can turn this whole house upside down if we want to. We have all the time in the world.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm afraid I don't understand. Nothing from Stolz. One of the men starts to roll up the carpet to look under it. Susan has to move out of his way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't you go upstairs?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm afraid she has to stay where we can see her -- in case she wanted to warn someone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My father's an M.P.!   Warn who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: EXT. DAN PIENAAR SCHOOL - DAY All four tires of Ben's car have been slashed to ribbons. INT. BEN'S GARAGE - DAY Ben and Johan are there. Ben takes a file from under a toolbox and measures it carefully against the drawer base. Then, he selects a piece of wood approximately the size of the drawer and tries it for size. We should be in no doubt that's he's constructing a hiding place. INT. BEN'S KITCHEN - AFTERNOON Susan is preparing a roast. There's music from a trans- istor RADIO. Susan is startled by a voice, her father's (Ben's FATHER-IN-LAW). She turns OFF, the RADIO.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roast beef, I hope it's like your mother's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Papa! He is aged about 70 years, thick set. She rushes to him and he hugs her tightly and practically lifts her off the floor. She kisses him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where's Mama? She disentangles herself and goes to the living room as excited as a child, the mother is standing by two cases, smiling. Susan hugs her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mama! She holds her mother at arm's length inspecting her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The perfume and a new hairstyle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your father insisted that I don't disgrace you. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I expected you a little later.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She insisted we start early. Where is Ben?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the study. I'll get him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you put on weight, Susan?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please don't say that, Papa. Ben walks in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry.   Didn't hear you arrive. He shakes hands with Father-In-Law.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How are you, Ben?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine. He goes to MOTHER-IN-LAW.        He kisses her on the cheek.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And how are you, Ma?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, Ben, still have trouble with my feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why doesn't everyone sit down?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll prepare some tea.     I baked a cake. She goes to the kitchen. EXT. LOCAL GOLF COURSE - SUNSET Ben and Father-In-Law are having a drink after a round of golf, outside the club house. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm getting tired of the trek to Cape Town and then back to Pretoria. If I had my way, Parliament and government would be in the same city. There's nothing wrong with Pretoria.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought you'd prefer Cape Town; the sea and Table Mountain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's for   holidays. Anyway, Ben, one of the   reasons for this visit was that I   wanted to have a discussion   with you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's that photograph in the papers. Ben, a thing like that could be an embarrassment for someone who is a member of Parliament. It's a grievous day when one's family's behavior comes between him and his duty to the fatherland.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you blaming me for trying to help those people?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've been doing that all my life, be they black or white. But no member of our family has been seen with a Kaffir woman before, Ben. Father signals the African waiter for more drinks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am glad you mentioned it, Father. Because I'd like to discuss the whole thing with you. First, there's the matter of Gordon Ngubene himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about him? I thought the case was closed. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. BEN'S LIVING ROOM - DAY The search continues in the living room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The black waiter places the drinks on the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's exactly what I said, Father, when Jonathan first got into trouble. Of course, they have good reasons: hushing up how Gordon died and how his son died!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ben, how could you side with the enemies of your people?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean you're prepared to sit back and allow an injustice to be done.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's you, Ben, who talk about injustice? A man who teaches history at school? Did you forget what our people have suffered under the English oppressors? Now that we have at along last come to power in our own land.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now we're free to do to others what they used to do to us. What will you do if you were a black man in this country today, Father?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you realize what the government is doing for the blacks? It's a slow process, Ben. One of these days the whole bloody lot of them will be free and independent in their own parts of the land, the bantoustans -- what can be more just than that? But they're not ready yet. The waiter returns -- Father-in-law pays the bill, and as he rises to leave, he puts a paternal arm on Ben's shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have nothing to be ashamed of before the eyes of the world, my boy. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We don't? I'm not sure we're going to survive. They walk away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't underestimate us, Ben.    Our power of survival. We are Afrikaners! EXT. STREET CORNER - EVENING Stanley is parked in a street corner in the last     white suburb on the way to Soweto. Ben pulls up in his      car behind Stanley's. He walks over to Stanley's car      and enters the back. Stanley smiles as he points at      his watch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: African time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry. They drive off towards Soweto.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doesn't matter, Lanie -- as long we are on time for the revolution.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The special branch searched my house four days ago.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The S.B. searches your house? (chuckles) Did they take anything?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A few journals, letters -- nothing much. Just wanted to scare me, that's all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't be so sure. They may think you're onto something big.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're not that stupid. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: Stanley laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Lanie' -- don't you believe it -- nothing's as stupid as the old S.B. If they decide it's a bomb they're looking for, you can shove a turd in their face and they'll swear to God it's a bomb. He laughs... making Ben smile. A pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And did they?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Scare you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.   They tried too hard. Stanley laughs again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hallelujah! (offers his huge hand) Shake, man. Join the club. Ben accepts the handshake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT. STANLEY'S CAR - NIGHT Ben and Stanley driving in Soweto. It's a different city by night. The dark seems to soften the violence of the confrontation, hiding the details which, by day, assault and insult the eyes. There are several GUNSHOTS in the distance. The only light comes from the small, square windows of the innumerable houses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you hear that, Lanie?     More kids dying? Ben says nothing. Further on there's a group of people outside a house.        As they pass they hear HYMN SINGING from the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's happening?   What's the singing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A wake for a child; eight months old. She was sleeping and they threw tear gas into it. They drive on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shakily) 'My dear wife, you must not worry about me. I miss you and the children. You must look after them in the fear of the Lord. I'm hungry, and I don't know what they want from me. But I think I'll be home some day. I think about...' They are interrupted by a KNOCK at the door. Emily snatches the notes and stuffs them into her bosom. Everyone is tense as Emily slowly walks up to the door. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: She opens it and   a man with a hat and dressed as a min- ister walks in.    Before anyone can say anything, Stanley bursts out in a   loud laugh. The man is slightly built, aged 40 years.    He is JULIUS NQAKULA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On your knees, everyone, prayers time. Ben is perplexed.    Emily closes the door and locks it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey man, you should have been a mfundisi holiness oozer...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, Stanley. It's stupid, but one is forced to do these things. He walks up to Ben and offers him his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm Julius Nqakula... I'm banned and also under house arrest. That's why I have this ridiculous garb on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I understand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's one of the most solid lawyers we have; they've immobilized him, that's the right word isn't it? He laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stanley has told me about you. I appreciate the risk you are taking by coming here to meet me. I was reading the notes Gordon smuggled out of John Vorster Square...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: May I have a glance at them? Emily produces the notes. Julius takes them. He starts reading the toilet paper, which is harder to read. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'My dear wife. I am still in these conditions... worse... and too much pain. They don't want to believe me. You must try to help me. They won't stop. You must care for the children. I don't know anymore if I will come home alive. They're very -- (a word mumbled)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The inquest didn't clear up half of what happened.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We have no irrefutable evidence yet, but we have enough to indicate that something serious is being covered up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know what I'm talking about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, Ben, I'm listening. Perhaps I can use my influence. But you'll have to convince me first.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If they have really nothing to hide, why is the special branch going out of its way to intimidate me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (practically choking) What's this about special branch?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They raided the house; they are tapping my phone, and I have been threatened by one of the officers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, Ben, I'd rather not have anything to do with this sort of thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If the special branch are involved they must have good reasons. (CONTINUED)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (standing, his golf bag in his hand)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. BEN'S LIVING ROOM - NIGHT Susan sitting on an armchair, sewing. She is aware of a car stopping opposite the house. Then several young voices shout: "Kaffir lover" "Kaffer boetie" "Red Communist" The car drives off at speed. Susan sits petrified.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. EMILY'S HOUSE - NIGHT Ben, Stanley and Emily are sitting    'round the table. Ben has pulled the lamp closer to read    one of two notes from Gordon -- one is written on ruled    paper, the other a square of toilet paper. The notes     have been smuggled out of John Vorster Square.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: but God will provide. I love you and I miss you very much. Try to help me because...' The voice breaks off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When did you get the letters?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The first one two days after they took him away. And the other one came later.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But, Emily, why didn't you tell me long ago?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I had given my word to the man
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: who brought them to me -- BEN Emily, I have to meet the man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He said he didn't want anybody to know who he is. I cannot make trouble for him in his work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He has to be persuaded.   He is very important to us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You as a lawyer will understand. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We intend starting a civil suit against the police, to do that it is necessary to have as many affidavits as we can from people who have any information about Gordon since he was arrested. And this man is vital and so is the Indian doctor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean Dr. Hassiem. How are you going to do that? You know of course that he is detained.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know, with luck they may release him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With luck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But, Emily, this man is important, please try to tell him we will protect his identity. No one will know. Nothing will be done without his approval. I only want to talk to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't you leave it to Stanley and I? What do you say, Stanley?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: May I call you Julius, I'm not very good with some African names.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nqakula, that's a hell of a name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please call me Julius.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This case must be reopened and we must win. We have to dig up everything. We need your cooperation, Julius. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where do I start? Don't forget my restrictions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They did not ban you so you could sit on your backside and have a Soweto holiday.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You could help with the affidavits. Lewinson the lawyer has stressed their importance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We know each other. He's a good lawyer for this kind of case. Of course I'll do what I can. My commitment forces me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm glad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How   are you planning to safeguard the   documents? Stanley told me you   have already had a said by the   S.B.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wouldn't worry.    I have a secure place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's hope so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll make some tea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not for me, Sis -- too strong for me. No whisky?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In my house? You know better than that, Stanley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tea then... (turning to Julius) ... and God forgive me -- CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT. BEN'S GARAGE - EVENING Ben is standing by the workbench, the new drawer he and Johan built for the toolbox, open before him. He's rereading Gordon's letters to Emily. Sound of approaching FOOTSTEPS. Ben quickly puts the letters into the drawer and shuts it. Susan appears at the door -- she looks ten years older.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ben, it's Johan. You'd better come. INT. BEN'S KITCHEN - EVENING Johan sits, Ben crouched before him.   The boy's shirt is torn, his eyes swollen, his lip cut.   He looks at the floor. Susan hovers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He won't tell me why it happened Ben holds his son's arms, gently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Johan.   Was it because of me? He doesn't answer for a moment.   Then he nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You see! It's gone too far, Ben. You've got to stop it...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shouting at his mother) I don't care! It doesn't hurt me! Susan stares at him, at Ben, turns abruptly, walks out of the room. Johan looks at his father.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was my friends, Dad. They're so stupid... They won't listen. They don't even want to know what you're trying to do. He's crying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you sure you know? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.   I know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does it worry you? Johan looks at his father through his tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't stop, Dad. You mustn't give up now! Ben hugs his son. MONTAGE The Gordon Ngubene name-cleaning team on the move. A)   BEN in a phone box dialing a number. B)   PHONE RINGING, RINGING, on a desk full of scattered files and papers. By the phone a photograph of a six- year-old Indian girl. C)   CLOSE ON NURSE Sound of the PHONE, a young nurse's frightened face as she remembers peering in at a young boy, struggling and moaning... Policemen closing the door... D)   CLOSE ON her hand signing the affidavit and handing it to a man's hand. E)   CLOSE ON Ben in the phone box hanging up the phone with rage. F)   CLOSE ON a young black man's face listening to Julius's voice:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... And on the morning of the autopsy, as I was cleaning the mortuary, Captain Stolz gave me a bundle of Ngubene's and ordered me to burn them. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: The young man nods. G)   BEN having a look on the two affidavits before hiding them into the drawer of the stool box. SHOTS.     Three!    Loud, sharp, terrifying. INT. BEN'S LIVING ROOM - LATE EVENING The WINDOW, a    LAMP and a MIRROR SHATTER -- Susan screams, standing, her    hands -- clamped over her ears -- eyes tight shut --    hysterical -- the TELEVISION CHATTERS on an Afrikaans'    play. Ben bursts in, holds her tight, as she screams into his chest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Call the police, Ben, call the police! Johan's voice comes from his room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Papa!    Papa!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's okay, son... we're all right. Everything's okay!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's happened?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's okay, stay there, please!! Gently, he leads Susan who is sobbing now, out of the room. INT. KITCHEN - LATE EVENING SUSAN (in disbelief) My God. They were trying to kill us. She's seated at the kitchen table. Ben has poured her a brandy which she cups in her hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They were trying to scare us, that's all. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction
