direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: Her fear turns into anger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, is that all... What the hell more do you want to happen... we're ordinary people for God's sake -- and you've pitched us into this -- this nightmare. I can't take any more, Ben... I can't take any more!! She drops her head and sobs. Ben sits beside her, and takes her hands to comfort her. Susan puts her head on his shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, Ben, stop. Just stop... please. Ben is obviously moved. He squeezes her hands, then takes her in his arms. INT. VILJOEN'S OFFICE - DAY The colonel, amiable, cool, behind his desk. A dishev- elled Ben, pitched angrily forward in his chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now you must be exaggerating, Mr. Du Toit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My house has been searched. My phone is tapped. My mail is opened. And last night three shots were fired through my window
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: close to killing my wife. Viljoen reacts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Du Toit, if shots were fired into your premises, we will investigate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All I want to know, Colonel, is why don't you leave me in peace? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now wait, wait a minute, Mr. Du Toit, you're not trying to blame me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me, Colonel, why is it so important to you people to stop my enquiries about Gordon Ngubene?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that what you are doing? (he pauses) Well, now. If you possess any information that may be of use to us, I trust you won't hesitate to discuss it with me. He leans forward towards Ben, his tone darkening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because if there are facts you are deliberately hiding from us, Mr. Du Toit -- If you give us reason to believe that you may be involved in activities that may be dangerous to both yourself and us
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: then I can foresee some problems.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that a threat, Colonel?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's call it a warning. A friendly warning. For God's sake, open your eyes, Mr. Du Toit! Don't you see you're being used!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By the Communists, I suppose. Ben gets up to go.    The colonel doesn't rise to see him out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goodbye, Colonel. (at the door, turning back) I'm sure. He leaves.    The colonel immediately picks up the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EXT. BEN'S KITCHEN - EARLY MORNING A 40-year-old African woman walks up to Ben's kitchen door. She knocks. Ben opens the door in pyjamas and dressing-gown.    She hands him a note and leaves. Ben reads the note and goes back into the house. EXT. STREET IN VREDEDORP - MORNING Vrededorp is a colored section of Johannesburg. It's rundown area vacated by whites. There are children play- ing in the street. Some unemployed men are sitting on old chairs outside a doorway; a vendor is serving two women from his milk churn. Ben drives into the street   searching for an address. He stops outside a house. As    he gets out of the car the children and everyone stop   to look at him with interest. He walks up to a door and   knocks. A COLORED WOMAN appears as the door opens.    She is young and obviously educated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Du Toit? Ben nods, hesitatingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, come in. Ben walks into the living/dining room. It's a    very tidy room with a three piece sitting room suite, a   sideboard with a clock on it. At one end of the room is    the dining area. The floor is linoleum and covered with    a rug in the middle. Stanley is lounging on a settee, beer in hand. On the chair next to him a black man in a brown striped suit, drinks orange squash. Thirtyish, pleasant face but very tense. He rises as Ben walks in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (rising and shaking hands with Ben) How's it? No trouble finding this place? You met Sadie. She's one of us. Ben nods to her. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And this is Johnson Seroke.    The man of the letters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Johnson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please sit down, Mr. Du Toit. A beer, tea or orange squash?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beer would be nice. Sadie goes to a cupboard and brings out a bottle of beer and a glass. She opens the beer and hands it to Ben. She disappears into the bedroom with a curtain at the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know they call this place Vrededorp, but we baptize it Malay Camp. Your first time in Malay Camp, Lanie?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've driven through here many times.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The main road, eh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiling) Ja. The woman re-enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll excuse me. Stanley, you know what to do with the key.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure, Sadie. And thank you. Can I help myself to another beer?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know it is. Goodbye, Mr. Du Toit, and you, be careful. To the Seroke. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, Sadie. Sadie leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That woman can die for you. We mustn't be long, Johnson has to be back on duty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alright, let's get on with it. Stanley tells me, you work at John Vorster Square.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I had no choice, they transferred me there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yet you smuggled out letters to Emily?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you do if a man asks you, and he's in trouble?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If they find out he'd be in very big trouble.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know that. Tell me, what do you know about Gordon?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You did talk to him from time to time?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gave me the letters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When was the last time you saw him? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just before he died.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you attend any of the interrogations?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I'm not a member of the Special Branch. But once I had to deliver a letter to Capt. Stolz, Gordon was there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How were they interrogating him? Seroke hesitates and looks at Stanley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's okay.   Tell him what you told me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They were using the pole.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The pole, what's that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They handcuff you and manacle your feet then they put a pole between your arms and the back of your knees. Then you're like a chicken ready for the oven. They hang you between two tables. Then they do what they like with you. The S.B. call it the aeroplane. Ben is horrified.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see. Who were in that room? Stolz...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lieutenant Venter and a black S.B. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are sure?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's sure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's very interesting. When was the last time you saw him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I saw them take the body away to the cells. He was limp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You did! Johnson, why do you stay with the police? You don't really belong there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a job. And how can I go away? I love my family. He jumps up and faces Ben with a look of anger and panic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They must never know I told you anything. Right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I understand.    I promise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is strictly between the three of us. Don't worry, man. Seroke shakes hands with them as he's leaving.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take it easy. Stanley goes to the cupboard for another beer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beer, Lanie?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, thank you. You know, Stanley, after what happened the other night I was about to give this whole thing up. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What happened, man?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My wife nearly got killed. Three shots were fired into the house. What right have I to expose my family to harassment and actual physical danger? That's what I asked myself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Three bloody shots and you crawl on your hands and knees to people like Stolz, and say 'I give up.' What is the beginning for you is a version of what we suffer all our bloody life. Shit, I thought you had more guts than this, man!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't say I'm giving up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you thought about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Johnson has revived my determination.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a hell of a time, Lanie, but we'll survive. You and me. I tell you!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You think we may still win in the end, Stanley?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course not, Lanie -- but we needn't lose either -- what matters is to stick around. Ben nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By the way, man, I'm off on a trip
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (pulling the fingers of his left hand one by one cracking the joints over and over)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Botswana -- thought I'd tell you in case you get worried.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why are you going there? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Business. Tell you next week. Now for the bad news I've been saving to the last.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Julius has been arrested. He broke his banning order and visited his sister. You know what that means? At least a year's imprisonment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A year in jail just for visiting his sister?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's the chance he took. And he'll be the last to complain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you think the real reason for this arrest was that they found out he was helping us?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So what? Lanie, you're not getting guilt complexes now, are you? That's a luxury only liberals can afford. Julius will be back, man. All refreshed by a spell in the deep-freeze.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How can we shrug off a man we've been working with?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who said we're shrugging him off? Best way of remembering a man, Lanie, is to carry on fighting. INT. BEN'S STUDY - DAY Ben's study is in chaos. The books have been plucked from the shelves and the contents of his drawers emptied on the floor. Ben standing in the middle of the room surveying the vandalism.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT. BRUWER KITCHEN - AFTERNOON This is a medium-sized kitchen with two doors leading from it, one to the dining room and the other to the living room. It has not changed since it was furnished twenty years ago, the only modern appliances being the electric stove and a modern mixer on the working table. Ben is leaning against the wall next to the door leading to the living room, drinking coffee. Melanie, bare-feet, her long black hair tied up in a ribbon, is washing up. She looks younger and fragile with this hair-style.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiling) What about you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I mean not married...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And living in this chaos with my eccentric father? I love him and we get on perfectly. We have been together since I was a year old. My mother could not adapt to South Africa. She went back to London and we've never heard from her since.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Being a professor and bringing up a child, how did he manage that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dorothy, dear Dorothy, she was a fantastic mother. In fact she had two families, me and her three children in Alexandra township.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And this little girl grew up to be a tough journalist. Why a journalist?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (laughs) Sometimes I ask myself the same question. She leans against the sink and picks up her mug of coffee. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alright. I'll tell you. I was brought up in a sheltered way, not that Dad was possessive, not openly anyway. I think he'd just seen enough of the mess the world was in, to want to protect me as much as he could. Then, I went to university. I don't know what you'll think... being a teacher. Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: About what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then I married my ex-teacher.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh.   He must have been young.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fifteen years difference. He too protected me like Dad. Then one day I visited Dorothy in Alexandra and saw her home and the appalling conditions in that township. I was shocked, Ben, and ashamed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go on. Melanie pours him another mug of coffee and starts to wipe up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That made me think that I was a parasite, something white and maggot-like... just a thing... a sweet and ineffectual thing. I felt more and more claustrophobic. Poor Brian, who loved and pampered me. Had no idea what was happening. I left him for a whole year and we divorced.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And then you became a journalist? Melanie goes to the living room, as she passes Ben she touches his arm and continues talking. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought it would force me, or help me, to expose myself. To force me to see and to take notice of what was happening around me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did it work? She returns to the kitchen with a cigarette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wish I could give you a straight answer. What did help me was my wanderings in Africa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How did you manage that on a South African passport? We South Africans are white devils in Africa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My mother was English, remember? So I get a British passport. It comes in handy even for the paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You really are your father's daughter!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wonder what he's doing right now. Most likely standing on a rock, looking through his old binoculars at springbok or a lion or whatever. One of the two large CATS approaches them, tail in the air, and goes to Melanie, drubbing against her legs, PURRING luxuriously. She picks it up into her arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How often does he go on these trips to the veldt?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It depends -- (approaching Ben with cat)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bonjour, Ben. I'm Porto and my friend is Bello! Ben smiles and starts to caress Porto in Melanie's arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EXT. SOWETO - EMILY'S HOUSE - MID-MORNING Parked outside the house is a municipality truck already half-laden with Emily's furniture and possessions. Four Africans in khaki overalls are loading the truck -- super- vising the eviction of Emily are a white Soweto official, Captain Stolz and Lt. Venter. In the b.g., a hundred yards away is a "hippo" with black and white armed policemen. Behind the truck are two police Land Rovers. Emily is sitting outside on one of her chairs as neighbors walk up to her to comfort her and say their goodbyes. Her daughter is carrying the youngest child and standing next to Emily -- several children are watching. A woman in the crowd starts singing a freedom song: "UMZIMA LOMTHWALO" ("THIS BURDEN IS HEAVY"). The song is taken up by the other women. Venter tries to stop them and disperse them. Stolz signals to him to leave them alone. One of the Africans then walks up to her for the chair. She refuses to get off the chair. The man looks at the white official as though to ask "what do I do." The official looks at Stolz. Venter walks up to Emily and, about to pull her off the chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you touch me! Venter pulls back. The women start to ululate. Emily rises majestically, takes the youngest in her arms and walks slowly to the truck followed by her daughter. People cluster around her, singing with rage and shaking her hand. Stolz observes the scene, impassive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come back!    Buya!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shouts) Buya!   Buya! Emily and the children are helped onto the back of the truck which drives away preceded by the police "hippo" and escorted from the rear by the Land Rovers. The crowd continues singing. EXT. STREET - MORNING Ben is leaving his home. This is a Saturday morning. Two men are sitting in a car a few yards from the entrance to the house. Ben doesn't pay attention to them. When he is about twenty yards past, one of the men, Jaimie -- who was present when Gordon was arrested -- gets out of the car and follows Ben. Ben stops at a corner for a car and again the FOOTSTEPS stop. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: He turns furtively and sees the man, stopped, turning his head. Ben decides to turn the corner, and listens to the FOOTSTEPS. The man is still following. Ben then decides to turn right back to have a good look at the man. They pass each other and Ben takes a good look at him and turns back onto the streets to the local shops. The man decides not to follow. INT. BEN'S STUDY - NIGHT Ben and Stanley sit. Ben on his desk. Stanley in an armchair with a drink. They look perplexed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's a widow, man. That's what happens in Soweto when a woman loses her man. They throw her out of the house and out of the city.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Zululand! The whole thing smells of being an excuse to send her hundreds of miles from the case. And how will they live there?...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shit! I was about to find her a place, but I had to go to look for Robert.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, that's why you went to Botswana for.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sis Emily asked me but it was no use. His mind was made up. He was going to join Wellington in Zambia.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Couldn't you stop him?   He's a little boy, Stanley! Stanley gulps down his whisky and stands up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He'll be back in a few years.     And he won't be throwing stones! Then, puts the empty glass on the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT./EXT. STANLEY'S HOUSE - EVENING Stanley peers through the curtains: he sees a car parked outside the house. In it Jaimie and another S.B. They are watching the house. Stanley quietly opens the door and walks outside. EXT. STANLEY'S HOUSE - EVENING Stanley walks past his car and approaches the policeman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (using his usual humor) Good evening. I'd like to invite you into my humble home, but it's full of terrorists. The two policemen get out of their car, obviously angry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (pointing at Stanley's car) Open the boot! You cheeky bastard!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, with pleasure. They search and find nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Open the door and remove the seat. Stanley executes the order. Jaimie and the OTHER POLICE- MAN peer in, their eyes sweeping the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, your pass, bliksem. Stanley   produces his passbook and hands it to the Police- man who   inspects the pages laboriously, then throws the book to   the ground. Stanley doesn't pick it up and just watches   the man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You watch your bloody step!     Right? They return to their car and drive off. Stanley looks at them thoughtfully, then picks up his book. EXT. DAN PIENAAR SCHOOL - MORNING All the students are in classes. Cloete walks        out of a classroom and sees Capt. Stolz walking towards       the build- ing. Cloete stops to wait for him. They shake         hands and walk to Cloete's office talking affably. They        enter office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT. BEN'S BEDROOM - NIGHT Ben and Susan in bed, asleep. The PHONE RINGS... waking them both. Ben answers. There's no one there. He puts it down. The RINGING STARTS AGAIN. Ben puts the re- ceiver down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (calmly) Ben, please stop whilst there's time. Please, Ben.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (focusing on ceiling) It's impossible to stop now, Susan. I believe I'm right in what I'm doing. If I stop now I'll go mad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (despaired) Whatever the price you pay for it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (painfully) I have got to. Susan shuts her eyes tight and turns her back on him to hide her tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Think of your heritage, man. My God -- think of your wife, your family, friends, neighbors. What's going to happened to them -- all of us -- if we can't depend on our own kind? We're educationalists -- teachers. We are building for the future.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Without simple justice we don't deserve a future.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're Boers, man -- Afrikaners. We are your nation. What's justice for us is justice -- period! (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Traitors like you are threatening centuries of Afrikaner sacrifice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That last remark was slanderous -- I'm simply being faithful to the truth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Slanderous? My God, man, you slander a whole people. He walks silently through the office then continues.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have given me no alternative. I have to abide by the regulations of the Department of Education -- so I have made my report. And there will have to be a formal inquiry. But until such time...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It won't be necessary, Mr. Cloete. I'll send you my resignation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you for making things much easier. Ben stares at him for a moment, then turns to leave.    As he reaches the door, Cloete says:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And it would be better if Johan left too. Ben turns to stare at him, amazed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you serious?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's a Kaffir-lover too, isn't he? The color drains from Ben's face. Then he steps forward, slaps Cloete thunderously across the face, hurling him back into his chair, and strides out, leaving the door ajar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EXT. SCHOOL YARD - LATE AFTERNOON It's the end of the school day. The yard is practically deserted. Only Viviers waiting for Ben under the veranda. Ben appears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oom Ben, I was waiting for you. I have something interesting to tell you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (striding on towards his car) Later, Viviers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (keeping up) But, Oom Ben, it's about the S.B. they came to question me. Before they started questioning me I told them they were wasting their time. Ben doesn't react.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They asked if I was cooperating with you. What I knew about the A.N.C. Can you imagine that! They then said: 'Mr. Viviers you come from a good Afrikaans family and it's important that you realize that communists are looking for people like you and before you know where you are they're using you! And, Oom Ben...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (reaching the car; interrupting him) I'm sorry, Viviers. I never wanted you to get involved. (getting into his car) I have just resigned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (amazed) What...? Ben drives away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT. BEN'S DINING ROOM - AFTERNOON Christmas day lunch. Assembled around the table are Ben's Father-in-law, his wife Helen, Suzette and Chris, her husband, Johan, Ben and Susan. They're all wearing paper hats from Christmas crackers. On the table is a large piece of roast lamb, ox tongue, a large turkey and assorted vegetables. Ben is at the head of the table adjacent to the door lead- ing to the kitchen, the Father-in-law is sitting by his side facing the door. Ben is in the middle of carving the turkey, plates are being passed to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Was last year's turkey as big as this, Papa?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: About the same size.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you remember the turkey I had for Easter? You said it was as big as a baby ostrich, Papa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't remember that, Suzette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, Johan, when I was a boy in the Karoo, we used to fry ostrich eggs. You know how big they are?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (laughing) As big as this table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Father-in-law) I think he deserves the parson's nose for that remark. They laugh. Susan laughs. She does her best to compose. Suddenly... a KNOCK at the outside kitchen door. As Ben turns towards the door it opens and... INT. BEN'S KITCHEN - AFTERNOON ... Stanley erupts into the kitchen like a great black bull in white suit and white shoes. A scarlet tie is matched by a huge handkerchief hanging from his pocket. He is a little drunk. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (obviously surprised by this family scene) Oh! (then grinning and laughing thunderously) Merry Christmas, everyone! There's deadly quiet -- not even the clink of a spoon -- as the Du Toits look on aghast. Slowly, as if in a dream, Ben rises and goes to Stanley who spots him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Lanie'... compliments of the season, old mate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stanley.   What are you doing here? Before Stanley answers, the Father-in-law gets up from his chair and goes to the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's this Kaffir, Ben?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't you tell the Boer who this Kaffir is?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shut up, Stanley. (to Father-in-law) That's all right. I'll...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A Kaffir calling me a Boer? Chris hurries into the kitchen ready for a fight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ben, did you hear that?   Call the police, Ben!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, go to the table. (to Stanley) Stanley, wait outside. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who are these people, anyway?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stanley, this is still my house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me throw him out. Ben steps between them and pushes Chris back into the dining room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let him try, leave him, Lanie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please leave me with him.   I'll explain everything later.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing has changed in this house. Mother, let's go! He strides into the dining room. INT. DINING ROOM - AFTERNOON Susan sits   with her eyes tight shut -- trying to shut out the horror   of it all. As the Father-in-law goes into the living   room, he pulls back his wife's chair and helps her to her   feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's leave this house. I've been sworn at by a Kaffir and Ben protects him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chris! Chris follows. Susan also. From the living room, she calls Johan who is left alone at the table, perplexed. Johan goes to his mother. There's a general rush for the door and, without warning, the room is empty. Only the TIN ANGELS TINKLE merrily around their candles. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT. KITCHEN - AFTERNOON STANLEY (with cascading laughter) Lanie! Ever in your fucking life seen such a stampede, hah?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (furious) Maybe you think it's funny, Stanley, but I don't. Do you realize what you've done? (he sighs deeply) Come into the dining room. Stanley follows Ben slowly, swaying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (chuckling) Jeez, who was that old cunt with the potbelly and black suit, looks like an undertaker? INT. DINING-ROOM - AFTERNOON Ben sits on his chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My father-in-law. (deliberately) M.P.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (sitting beside Ben) You joking! (he laughs) Shit! I fucked it all up for you. Sorry, man. He laughs again.   Ben cannot take it anymore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now pull yourself together, Stanley. It's not funny at all! What's the matter with you today? You're drunk and making an idiot of yourself. Say what you've come to say. Otherwise, go to hell! Stanley's laughter changes into a broad grin. He sur- veys the table and takes a bit of turkey from a plate and starts to eat it quietly. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right. Dead right. Put the Kaffir in his place. Ben grabs him by the shoulders and starts to shake him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bloody hell! Stanley, what's wrong with you? Stanley shoves Ben off, and glares at him, bloodshot eyes breathing heavily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emily is dead. Ben stares at him in stunned disbelief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Emily dead?   How?   When? Stanley doesn't answer - he cries. Ben grabs him by the shoulders and shakes him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What happened, Stanley?      Oh, my God. Please tell me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A broken heart. All they said. Ben's hand still on Stanley's shoulder, he sits slowly beside him, shaken, his face ravaged by the news.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God. Through the window, he sees Suzette and Chris carrying suitcases, back down the path to his in-laws' car; Father-In-Law shepherding his wife and an ashen, dazed Susan, helping them into the car. As they leave see Johan leaning against the dining room door, watching his father and Stanley. INT. BRUWER HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - LATE EVENING A very tense Ben is sitting on Professor Bruwer's chair. Melanie is curled up on the old settee. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They don't know what you've got and you're a danger to them. I know there's a point of no return, but with our system, one has to plot the route with care.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's the main reason for coming here tonight. Melanie, I need your help. Without Emily, we can't pursue our civil suit. The only thing left open to us is to expose them through the press, and the media here and abroad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And your safety also, Ben, lies in the press. (pause) That way the world will know the brutality and power of our security services; here questions can be asked in Parliament. And the white public can appreciate the implications of the fascist laws of this country.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, Melanie, I'm discovering that the enemy is not in Soweto. The enemy is ourselves. Our bigotry, our laws, our system. We have our own fight and it's just beginning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We better win before the blacks have won. Ben and Melanie laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, before going to the press, I have to have all the documents. I must have two vital affidavits; Dr. Hassiem's, he's detained and Jonathan's friend, Wellington has fled to Zambia.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Zambia? I'm going to Rhodesia... I can go to Zambia. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Could you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I can use my British passport. I know my way around Lusaka.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That would be very useful. Melanie jumps off the settee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This calls for a drink.    Gin and tonic?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please. As Melanie walks away, Ben looks at her with admiration and tenderness... her dress swinging around her legs... her bare feet soundless on the floor... the quiet grace of her movement. On the way to the kitchen to get the drinks, Melanie goes to the record player. There's a record already on the turntable. Suddenly as if rising from a dream, Ben murmurs:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Melanie.   Be careful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course, Ben. She goes into the kitchen. As Melanie hums to herself to     the BLUES MUSIC, in the kitchen, Ben walks over to the     window and furtively glances out, to assure himself     that nobody is watching. He takes then a book on a pile     next to the settee and pages slowly through it. Melanie returns with two glasses, still in her happy mood. She places Ben's glass on the side table next to the settee, takes the book from him and makes him sit down. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cheers! Ben raises his glass and touches it with hers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do be careful. I wouldn't want you hurt. She reaches for his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And hurry back. A new track starts on the RECORD.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's my favorite, Ben. Jumping up and taking Ben's glass and placing it on the side table, she pulls him to his feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't dance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rugger player? They laugh as they start to dance to the slow BLUES MUSIC. The laughing subsides as they hold each other closer. The dancing starts to lose the beat of the music. They look into each other's eyes and Ben envel- ops her tenderly in his arms hugging her as close as possible against him. They stop dancing.     Ben kisses her.   A long, warm and tender kiss. INT. MELANIE'S BEDROOM Ben and Melanie in bed. He is kissing her and fondling her passionately. During the love play, Ben reaches for the lightswitch of the bedside lamp, and knocks it over. They make love.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT. LOCAL SUPERMARKET - MORNING Ben is shopping at the local supermarket. He    is pushing a trolley. As he places some groceries into    his trolley, he notices a man standing near the check-out   counters. The man is similar built as Jamie and similar   hairstyle. He's reading a newspaper, his face concealed. Ben drops the package he was inspecting, back on the shelf and pushes his trolley towards the man to try and see his face. The man moves away. Ben follows him and has decided to confront him. Man picks up a pack of ham. Ben is about to remonstrate with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Listen, you... Just then a LADY and her daughter hurry to the man, push- ing a trolley. Man turns to look at Ben.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darling, put that down, it's not good for your cholesterol.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to the man) I'm sorry, my mistake. He pushes his trolley away embarrassed. EXT. SUZETTE'S HOUSE - SWIMMING POOL - DAY The immaculate blue of the pool. Johan hurls himself out of the water, flops down at the side. Suzette and Ben nearby, sitting in the sun. Pieter at the barbecue, sizzling thick steaks. A servant in white uniform soundlessly laying the table on the patio behind him. The nanny with the baby in the shade.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How's she doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Better... She's waiting for you to ask her to come home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I doubt it. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: She turns to Ben, squinting in the sun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Papa, I don't want to interfere...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then don't. A pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know this is going to sound strange coming from me... I mean I haven't exactly been supportive for the past months... I can't say I agree with what you've done but I respect you for what you are... ON Johan listening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm just... destroyed by what's happening to us as a family.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suzette...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, Papa, for Mom's sake... For all of our sakes... Let's try and patch it up. Ben smiles sadly at her... Suzette understands.        Johan looks at them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suzette leans in through the driver's window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me know if there's anything I can do to help.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks.   I'm glad you understand. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want to worry about you. That search, this vandalism, those shots... they're really after the evidence you've been accumulating ... Can I look after them for you, Papa? Ben smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't have to worry.   They'll never find them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where on earth do you keep them? ON Johan looking at Suzette then at Ben with concern. EXT. INDIAN TOWNSHIP - DAY Ben has parked his car in a street corner of the upmarket section of the Asian township. He peers around him, then walks away. Ben knocks at a door. The door is opened cautiously by DR. HASSIEM, a tall, handsome Indian, aged 35 years. His clothes are casual but expensive. His six-year-old daughter, large dark eyes, is clinging to his leg. We recognize the little girl of the photograph near the telephone, from earlier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dr. Hassiem? I'm Ben Du Toit. I'm a friend of Gordon Ngubene's...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The inquest is over, Mr. Du Toit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not for me, Doctor. I've got to know what happened to Gordon. Dr. Hassiem looks shaky, nervous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I only came home yesterday. After three months in detention and now I'm banned and confined to the house. There's nothing I can do for you. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: The little girl still clinging to his leg, watching Ben.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know it may be painful to you, Doctor, but I need to talk to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How can I be sure you weren't actually sent by them?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ask Emily. Doctor, we are in the process of filing a civil claim. And your help is vital. Hassiem gives Ben a long look.    He picks up his daughter and opens the door fully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come in. Ben walks into the large living room, tastefully furnished.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sit down. Ben is still looking 'round at the opulence.       He sits in a chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you for inviting me in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you want to know?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just one thing, Doctor. Why did you sign the State Pathologist's report on the autopsy if you drew up your own report as well?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What makes you think I signed Dr. Jansen's report.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The report produced in court had both your signatures on it. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Impossible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What did you write in your report?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dr. Jansen and I didn't disagree on the facts. After all we examined the same body in the same time. But just on the interpretation. For example, if Gordon, had really been hanged, the marks on his throat would have been concentrated on the front. (he touches his larynx) But in this case, the bruises were more obvious on the sides. Pause.   Ben nods, silent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Something else really upset me, perhaps it isn't important.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What was it? Dr. Hassiem puts down his daughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You see, through a misunderstanding I arrived at the morgue too early for the autopsy. There wasn't a soul around except a young African attendant. When I told him I'd come for the autopsy, he let me in. The body was on the table dressed. I noticed blood on the clothes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And then?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As I examined the clothes more closely, a police-officer came in and said I wasn't allowed in the morgue before Dr. Jansen arrived. When I returned with Dr. Jansen, half an hour later, the body was naked. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doctor, we've already got the African attendant's affidavit. He testified that Capt. Stolz ordered him to burn the clothes. (pause) Did you mention what you said in your report?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course.   I found it most odd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doctor Hassiem would you be prepared to put that in writing? Dr. Hassiem thinks it over for a while then:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please excuse me for a minute. Ben watches him leave the room, the little girl following him. He gets up from the chair, walks to the window, glances through it, then steps to look at some family photographs on the mantlepiece. Amongst them a photograph of Dr. Hassiem before "Big Ben." Dr. Hassiem returns with a file, the daughter still following.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is my report. I only have one copy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have a copy of the report? Hassiem grins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know how to hide things from the S.B., Mr. Du Toit. Ben congratulates him by a deep laughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: On Dr. Hassiem's desk we recognize next to the phone, the little girl's photograph.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope you have as secure a place as I have.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think so. INT. BUILDING IN CONSTRUCTION - LATE AFTERNOON A multi-storied building half-built. Stanley standing on the fourth floor watching Ben's arrival. Ben searches for Stanley who draws Ben's attention; beckons him up. Ben indicates they meet halfway. He joins Stanley who's sitting on a pile of bricks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take a pew, man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have it, Stanley!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hassiem's report. You know what that means, Stanley? Melanie arrives in two days. We'll have all the evidence. Everything is in place. We'll get them yet, especially Stolz.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's fantastic, man. Stanley produces from his jacket pocket a newspaper -- Rand Daily Mail. He opens it on a certain page with the picture of an African in police uniform, and hands it to Ben.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God!   It's Johnson Seroke. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Late at night. A knock on the door. He opened and five shots, point-blank range. Face, chest, stomach.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. CLOETE'S OFFICE - LATE AFTERNOON It's a functional office. Picture of the South African president (1976) John Vorster, on the wall. Various staff pictures... Ben, summoned by Cloete, sits.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as she plays the record and flippantly)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT. SUZETTE'S HOUSE - LATER Ben and Johan in the car.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . HASSIEM (the little girl on his knees)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. HASSIEM'S OFFICE - DAY Ben and Dr. Hassiem working as a team, tape the type- written sheets of the report among a Rand Daily Mail newspaper pages at the back. (CONTINUED)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: police spokesman when questioned said: "It's not the first time that a black member of the police has lost his life in the service of his country, fighting terrorism." (folding paper in disgust) Bloody bastards! They killed him. Stolz must have thought he knew too much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the score? The nurse is detained; the mortuary attendant has disappeared; the police van driver who brought Jonathan to hospital is detained. Julius is in jail, and now Johnson dead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's next on their secret list, I wonder? How much longer must the list grow of those who pay the price of our efforts to clear Gordon's name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey! Are you going soft, Lanie? We must keep going even more so now. And for every bloke who's going to die of bloody natural causes in their hands. And for our children's future.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know. If I can no longer believe that right is on my side, if I can no longer believe in imperative to go on, what will become of me, Stanley? Ben looks at Johnson's picture again and shakes his head. INT. BEN'S STUDY - DAY A 8x10 black and white photograph on Ben's desk. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: On the photograph a naked man and a girl on a bed and a bedside lamp on its side. The man is Ben and the girl is Melanie. Stolz in sports jacket, standing next to the desk is speaking... patronizing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're all made of flesh and blood, Mr. Du Toit -- we've all got our flaws. And if a man likes to sample the grass on the other side of the fence, well, that's his own business. But it would be unpleasant if people found out about it, especially if he's a teacher.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean, if I cooperate, if I stop digging, embarrassing you, threatening you... these photographs will disappear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's just say I may be able to use my influence to make sure that a private indiscretion isn't used against you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suppose I refuse? Stolz looks past Ben.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is this your son? Ben whirls around to see Johan at the door. He shoots, puts himself between the photograph and his son obviously surprised to find Capt. Stolz there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Johan, leave us alone, please. Johan walks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you think this business has gone long enough? Ben, struggling to maintain his composure. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's for you people to decide. Isn't it? I won't be blackmailed, Captain -- not even by you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mind if I smoke? Ben answers by a gesture.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now be honest. Has all the evidence you've been collecting in connection with Gordon Ngubene brought you closer to the truth you are looking for?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I think so and there's more to come. A pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I really hoped we could talk man-to-man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not possible, Captain.    Not between you and me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's high time, Mr. Du Toit, we allowed the dead to rest in peace. I'm offering you a chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean my very last chance?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One never knows. It may not be important to you, but we have to survive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If we can only survive through murder and torture, then we have forfeited our right to exist. Slowly and deliberately Stolz stubs out his cigarette in the ashtray. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that your final answer?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Before you go. I'll tell this, Captain. I have a pretty good idea of what I will eventually uncover. I mean the truth. And I won't allow anyone or anything to come between me and that truth. Ben walks up to the door to see him out. There's no response from Stolz. He calmly takes a small card out of his pocket and rests it on Ben's desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here's my card -- my private line. If you should change your mind... Let's say before the end of the week?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goodbye, Captain, and don't forgt the photograph. Stolz picks up the photograph and puts it into his briefcase.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Be careful, Mr. Du Toit. There are people who can make things very difficult for you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are wasting their time. They just can't hurt me anymore. I trust you'll give them the message, Captain. He walks out. Ben follows him 'round the garage and watches him get into his car and drive away. Johan joins his father.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A brandy, Papa?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A gin and tonic would be fine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INT. JAN SMUTS AIRPORT - DAY Ben and Johan are standing in the public enclosure on the top floor of the airport building. Ben is unshaved, he looks tired, but happy. There is the usual bustle of airport staff for the steps and luggage, two-thirds of the staff being black. Passengers emerge from the plane Melanie amongst them. Some waving to friends and relatives on the public en- closure. Melanie stops momentarily and looks up at the enclosure. She sees Ben and Johan and waves at them. They wave back and Ben indicates they'll be waiting for her below. She walks off as they happily await her after the ususal formalities. INT. JAN SMUTS AIRPORT - DAY Ben and Johan are waiting outside the arrivals exit. Several passengers stream out, some being met. Eventually there is a trickle of passengers. An INDIAN WOMAN is one of the last to come out. Ben approaches her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me, I'm waiting for a lady with a red dress. Are there still, many people to come?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I did see her. She was ahead of me. Maybe she's still in there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. Just then an OFFICIAL walks out of the door.   Ben hurries to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I help you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm waiting for a passenger, Miss Bruwer. She's taking a rather long time to be cleared.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What did you say her name was?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Melanie Bruwer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll go and check. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: The Official hurries back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is there any other exit, Papa?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. They have to collect their luggage and pass through customs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe she can't find her bag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's possble. Just then Stolz appears through the door. He slowly walks up to Ben and Johan. Ben becomes apprehensive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Afternoon, Meneer Du Toit.   Johan, isn't it? Ruffling his hair; Johan pulling away and glaring at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What now, Captain?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Word came to me that you were asking after your very good friend, Miss Bruwer. You know, subersives come in all guises and can be very resourceful. Now let's take your friend, she has been using her privilege as a journalist to endanger the security of this country. But you know something else? She has been secretly holding a British passport. A South African passport and a British pasport. Now you tell me, where is her patriotism? Her allegiance? The minister telexed to the immigration officers here declaring her an undesirable immigrant. So she is being put on the first available plane to London. This must be heart- breaking for you. Good afternoon, Meneer Du Toit, Johan. Stolz walks back. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's go home, Johan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't understand, Papa...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll explain later. They hurry out of the building in silence. EXT. BEN'S HOUSE - DAY Ben and Johan arriving at the house. An unsympathetic small crowd is there waiting... They react, murmuring in Afrikaans, watching them with hostility as Ben and Johan get out of the car and discover the chaos. The wreckage. The garage and Ben's study have been bombed. Johan leaves Ben and rushes to the house. The crowd starts to disperse. The entire    tools cupboard has been methodically ripped apart and    the contents strewn on the garage floor. Everything    is half-burnt... charred... Ben has sunk onto the stool    in total defeat. There's silence. Then Johan appears at the door. He hands Ben a large envelope -- in it, the file with all the papers. Ben looks up at Johan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I took it out. Hide it in my secret place. Ben grabs his son, hugs him and holds on for dear life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, son. You did a man's job.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: Before him, scattered on the table: the affidavits he collected, the Hassiem report, cuttings of articles by Melanie in the Rand Daily Mail about Jonathan, newspaper pictures of Gordon, of Seroke, of himself with Emily, the half-burnt "peace painting" of Picasso, half-burnt photo of Ben with Suzette, a staff photograph, Ben amongst it, and a charred trophy. Ben starts putting material relevent to his inquiries into a large brown envelope. Johan enters kitchen with a large envelope and hands it to his father.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Somebody has dropped it through the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm nearly ready, Papa. Ben examines the unstamped envelope with his address, with curiosity then opens it. The contents is Wellington's affidavit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wellington's affidavit! He looks inside the envelope, expecting a personal note. There's none.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good old Melanie!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED: Johan gets on the bike and rides out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Meneer du Toit, tonight we're coming to kill you. Ben replaces the receiver obviously shaken.     He becomes aware of FOOTSTEPS approaching the kitchen.     Ben is terrified. A KNOCK at the door and the door swings open:     it's Stanley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's happened, man?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's you. It was a bomb.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the papers?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry. Safe. Thanks to Johan. Incidentally, I have Wellington's affidavit. Melanie found him. She's being deported. The official reason is that she possessed a British passport. I don't know how she managed to smuggle the envelope to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Man, it's all happening! Stanley walks out, glances at the devastated study. He reenters the kitchen and slams on a chair. He takes a packet of "Lucky Strike" from his pocket and offers it to Ben (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like a joint?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, thanks. Stanley lights a cigarette and surveys the table. He picks up the half-burnt Picasso book, gives it a brief glance, and tosses it back on the table and starts to chuckle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's so funny?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They drop the bomb on you! Ben walks up to him puts his hand on his shoulder. There's an understanding trace of a smile on his face. INT. CAFE - DAY Ben sitting in a cafe smoking his pipe.   A waiter serves him a glass of beer, for which he pays.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How are you, Suzette? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, Papa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you like a drink?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, thanks. Without taking his eyes off her, he takes a brown envelope from a chair and pushes it slowly towards the uncomfor- table Suzette. She picks up the envelope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have to go, Papa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know. Suzette awkwardly kisses him on the cheek.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look after them. Suzette looks at him for a moment and hurries to her car. As Suzette leaves, Ben turns back into the room, his eyes glassy with tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Colonel Viljoen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see you got the goodies. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was on my way to your office, Colonel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We thought we'd save you the trouble, Mrs. Klopper. She hands Viljoen the envelope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here it is, Colonel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. This country needs more people like you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I must hurry, Colonel.   Goodbye. She drives off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now let's see what we've got.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. BEN'S STUDY - DAY Ben is sitting at the kitchen table. (CONTINUED)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. JOHAN'S BEDROOM - DAY Johan is packing his sport kit and few clothes into a bag.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT. BEN'S HOUSE - DRIVEWAY - DAY Ben and Johan are walking towards the entrance, Johan wheeling his bike. Ben hugs his son. (CONTINUED)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. BEN'S KITCHEN - DAY Ben is pouring coffee. He looks tired and tensed. The PHONE RINGS in the living room. He hurries to answer it. Who knows, could be Melanie from the airport! INT. LIVING ROOM - DAY Ben picks up the phone.    A menacing male voice says:
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT. JOHANNESBURG STREET - DAY It's raining. Stanley driving in the rain on the same road as Johan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT. CAFE - PASSENGERS' POV FROM PARKED CAR - DAY Suzette's sports car pulls up outside the cafe where Ben is waiting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. CAFE - DAY Ben rises as Suzette joins him at his table.   They kiss and she sits opposite him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking at her straight in the eyes)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT. STREET CAFE - DAY Suzette gets into her car and drives off. The parked car follows. The two cars turn at the next corner. EXT. QUIET STREET The two cars approach following each other. As the second car overtakes, he draws Suzette's attention with his HORN and signals her to pull up. As she gets out of her car holding the brown envelope, Capt. Stolz gets out of the other side. Suzette walks over to the passenger:
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. CAPTAIN STOLZ'S CAR - DAY Stolz gets into the car as Colonel Viljoen starts open- ing the brown envelope.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : EXT. RAND DAILY MAIL BUILDING - DAY Stanley is parked near the building. He's drumming on the steering wheel to the rhythm of AFRICAN MUSIC from his car RADIO.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : INT. STOLZ'S CAR - DAY Viljoen has just finished opening the brown envelope. He pulls out the half-burnt Picasso book and Captain Stolz's card which he gave to Ben. On the card is written:
dialogue.name: dialogue
